title: Neu-Thierstein Castle
text:
Neu-Thierstein Castle is a ruined castle in the <a href="Switzerland">Swiss</a> <a href="Municipalities%20of%20Switzerland">municipality</a> of <a href="B%C3%BCsserach">Büsserach</a> in the <a href="canton%20of%20Solothurn">canton of Solothurn</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.
History.
The castle was founded in 1100 and a new building was built around 1294/95. The castle was apparently built by the Saugern-Pfeffingen family as a seat for a "Kastvogtei" (or a <a href="vogt">vogt</a> with authority over a religious structure) who ruled over <a href="Beinwil%20Abbey">Beinwil Abbey</a>. The first mention of the castle comes from 1321 when it was called "Bello". As heirs of the Saugern-Pfeffingen family, in the late 12th Century, the <a href="count%20of%20Thierstein">count of Thierstein</a> took over the castle and the "Kastvogtei" post. By 1400 it was known as Thierstein Castle. The castle was occupied by the Canton of Solothurn in 1445, 1467 and 1499. After the extinction of the counts of Thierstein in 1522, Solothurn acquired the castle and made it the administrative center of the secular <a href="bailiwick">bailiwick</a> of Thierstein. In 1798 the castle was sold for demolition. However, in the 19th Century, the destruction of the castle are stopped by private individuals who wanted to repair the ruins. The ruins were surveyed and archeologically investigated in 1985.
Castle site.
The castle ruins are on a small rocky outcrop above the municipality of Büsserach. The ruin consists of a residential tower with ancillary buildings. Traces of a <a href="Motte-and-bailey">bailey</a> and the old gate house on the south side can still be seen.
